revision.text:
{{Italic title}} [[File:Joseph S. Nelson - Fishes of the World.jpeg|200px|right]] '''''Fishes of the World''''' by [[Joseph S. Nelson]] is a standard reference for [[fish]] [[systematics]]. Now in its fifth edition (2016), the work is a comprehensive overview of the diversity and classification of the 30,000-plus fish [[species]] known to science.
The book begins with a general overview of [[ichthyology]], although it is not self-contained. After a short section on [[Chordata]] and non-fish [[taxa]], the work lists all known fish families in a systematic fashion. Each [[family (biology)|family]] gets at least one paragraph, and usually a body outline drawing; large families have subfamilies and tribes described as well. Notable [[genera]] and species are mentioned, while the book generally does not deal with the species-level diversity. The complexities of the higher taxa are described succinctly, with many references for difficult points. The book does not involve color illustrations.
The fourth edition was the first to incorporate the wide use of [[DNA]] analysis, revising many earlier classifications.
The first edition appeared in 1976, the second in 1984, the third in 1994 ([[John Wiley & Sons]], {{ISBN|0-471-54713-1}}), the fourth in March 2006 ({{ISBN|0-471-25031-7}}), and the fifth in April 2016 ({{ISBN|9781118342336}}).
==References== *''Fishes of the World''. by Joseph S. Nelson. Review by: Michael A. Bell (1995) ''The Quarterly Review of Biology'' Vol. 70, 232-233 https://www.jstor.org/stable/3036281 *''Fishes of the World''. by Joseph S. Nelson. Review by: [[Carl L. Hubbs]] (1977) ''Systematic Zoology'' Vol. 27, 136-137 https://www.jstor.org/stable/2412830 * ''Fishes of the World''. by Joseph S. Nelson. Review by: [[George C. Williams (biologist)|George C. Williams]] (1977) ''The Quarterly Review of Biology'' Vol. 52, 215-216. https://www.jstor.org/stable/2824104 *''Fishes of the World'' by J. S. Nelson. Review by: Lynne R. Parenti (1995) ''Copeia'' Vol. 1995, 262-264 https://www.jstor.org/stable/1446836 * {{Cite journal| doi = 10.1111/j.1467-2979.2006.00227.x| issn = 1467-2979| volume = 7| issue = 4| pages = 334–334| last = Day| first = Julia J.| title = Fishes of the World, 4th Edition| journal = Fish and Fisheries| accessdate = 2015-08-31| date = 2006-12-01| url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1467-2979.2006.00227.x/abstract}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20131213153622/http://members.shaw.ca/fishesoftheworld/editions.htm ''Fishes of the World'' (4th edition) Homepage] * [https://sites.google.com/site/fotw5th/ ''Fishes of the World'' (5th edition) Homepage] (includes updated [https://sites.google.com/site/fotw5th/home/FotW5Classification.pdf?attredirects=0 classification])

{{Unreferenced|date= January 2007}} Typical '''Flora of Malta''' consists of the following [[plants]] and [[flowers]]. While small compared to other [[country|countries]], the [[Malta|Maltese Islands]] contain special [[flower]]s that grow on [[island]]s such as [[Malta (island)|Malta]], [[Gozo]], [[Comino]], [[Filfla]], [[St Paul's Island]]s and [[Fungus Rock]].
==Maltese Everlasting== *Scientific Name: ''[[Helichrysum melitense]]'' *Maltese Name: Sempreviva ta' Għawdex
A rare endemic [[shrub|bush]] growing up to one metre and found only on the western [[cliff]]s of Gozo and on Fungus Rock. Its bright [[yellow]] flowers can be seen around May and June. Its long and narrow whitish [[leaves]] have a covering of short hair.
==Hoary Rock-Rose== *Scientific name: ''[[Cistus creticus]]'' *Maltese name: Ċistu Roża
A very scarce wild flower found mainly in [[garrigue]], where occasionally it is the dominant species. Its pinkish red large flowers appear in spring, on a shrub with sticky [[leaf|leaves]].
==Evergreen Rose== *Scientific Name: ''[[Rosa sempervirens]]'' *Maltese Name: Girlanda tal-Wied
A rare [[perennial plant|perennial]] [[evergreen]] climber with thorny [[plant stem|stems]], glossy [[compound leaves]] and shiny red [[fruit]]. Its white flowers appear in spring and early summer. Found growing in maquis and on the sides of sheltered [[valley]]s.
==Wild Artichoke== *Scientific Name: ''[[Cynara cardunculus]]'' *Maltese Name: Qaqoċċ tax-Xewk
A common perennial with very large spiny leaves, generally flowering in early summer. It has large deep bluish-violet flower heads, and grows in [[steppe]]s, especially on [[clay]] and [[garrigue]], sometimes even on disturbed ground..
==Maltese Pyramidal Orchid== *Scientific Name: ''[[Anacamptis urvilleana]]'' *Maltese Name: Orkida Piramidali ta' Malta
A scarce endemic [[orchid]], resembling the common [[Pyramidal Orchid]], but having smaller and paler [[pink]] or [[white]] flowers. Flowers can be found from February to April in [[garrigue]] and rocky [[steppe]]s.
==Pheasant's Eye== *Scientific Name: ''[[Adonis microcarpa]]'' *Maltese Name: Għallet is-Serduq
A rare [[annual plant|annual]] [[wild flower]] with delicate fine leaves and bright red flowers appearing during the months of winter and spring. They grow in cultivated land. Heavily persecuted through picking.
==Sea Daffodil== *Scientific Name: ''[[Pancratium maritimum]]'' *Maltese Name: Pankrazju
==Southern Dwarf Iris== *Scientific Name: ''[[Iris pseudopumila]]'' *Maltese Name: Bellus
==French Daffodil== *Scientific Name: ''[[Narcissus tazetta]]'' *Maltese Name: Narċis
==Yellow-throated Crocus== *Scientific Name: ''[[Crocus longiflorus]]'' *Maltese Name: Żagħfran Salvaġġ
==Large Star of Bethlehem== *Scientific Name: ''[[Ornithogalum arabicum]]'' *Maltese Name: Ħalib it-Tajr Kbir
==Wild Tulip== *Scientific Name: ''[[Tulipa sylvestris]]'' *Maltese Name: Tulipan Salvaġġ
==Common Poppy== *Scientific Name: ''[[Papaver rhoeas]]'' *Maltese Name: Peprin
==Red Campion== *Scientific Name: ''[[Silene colorata]]'' *Maltese Name: Lsien l-Għasfur
==Corn Chamomile== *Scientific Name: ''[[Anthemis arvensis]]'' *Maltese Name: Bebuna tar-Raba'
==Borage== *Scientific Name: ''[[Borago officinalis]]'' *Maltese Name: Fidloqqom
==Crown Daisy== *Scientific Name: ''[[Chrysanthemum coronarium]]'' *Maltese Name: Lellux
==Common Mallow== *Scientific Name: ''[[Malva sylvestris]]'' *Maltese Name: Ħobbejża Komuni
==Virgin Bush== *Scientific Name: ''[[Vitex agnus-castus]]'' *Maltese Name: Sigret il-Virgi
==Spanish Broom== *Scientific Name: ''[[Spartium junceum]]'' *Maltese Name: Genistra Safra
==Mediterranean Hawthorn== *Scientific Name: ''[[Crataegus azarolus]]'' *Maltese Name: Għanzalor
==Judas Tree== *Scientific Name: ''[[Cercis siliquastrum]]'' *Maltese Name: Siġra ta' Ġuda
==Myrtle== *Scientific Name: ''[[Myrtus communis]]'' *Maltese Name: Riħan
==Lentisk== *Scientific Name: ''[[Pistacia lentiscus]]'' *Maltese Name: Deru
==Sources== [http://www.maltawildplants.com www.Maltawildplants.com]
{{Flora of Europe}}
[[Category:Flora of Malta| ]] [[Category:Lists of plants|Malta]] [[Category:Lists of biota of Malta|Flora]]

revision.text:
{{technical|date=February 2014}} [[File:Saturn eclipse.jpg|thumb|Saturn [[eclipse]]s the Sun, as seen from the ''[[Cassini–Huygens|Cassini]]'' [[space probe]]. The forward [[light scattering by particles|scattering of light]] makes the faint outer rings more visible.]]
In [[physics]], [[telecommunications]], and [[astronomy]], '''forward scatter''' is the [[deflection (physics)|deflection]]—by [[diffraction]], nonhomogeneous [[refraction]], or nonspecular [[reflection (physics)|reflection]] by particulate matter of dimensions that are large with respect to the [[wavelength]] in question but small with respect to the [[beam diameter]]—of a portion of an incident [[electromagnetic wave]], in such a manner that the energy so deflected propagates in a direction that is within 90° of the direction of [[wave propagation|propagation]] of the [[Ray (optics)#Interaction with surfaces|incident wave]] (i.e., a [[phase angle (astronomy)|phase angle]] greater than 90°).
The [[scattering]] process may be sensitive to [[polarization (waves)|polarization]]; that is, the polarization of incident waves that are identical in every respect may be scattered differently. Forward scatter differs from [[backscatter]].
== Comets == Forward scattering can make a back-lit comet appear significantly brighter because the dust and [[ice crystal]]s are reflecting and enhancing the apparent brightness of the comet by scattering that light towards the observer.<ref name="scattering">{{cite web |title=Comet Elenin as seen by STEREO-B, and what we think is going to happen next... |publisher=Sungrazing Comets |url=http://sungrazer.nrl.navy.mil/index.php?p=Elenin |accessdate=2011-08-05}}</ref> Comets studied forward-scattering in visible-thermal photometry include [[Comet Skjellerup–Maristany|C/1927 X1 (Skjellerup–Maristany)]], [[Comet West|C/1975 V1 (West)]], and C/1980 Y1 (Bradfield).<ref name=Marcus2007>{{cite journal |last=Marcus |first=Joseph C. |title=Forward-Scattering Enhancement of Comet Brightness. I. Background and Model |journal=International Comet Quarterly |volume=29 |issue=2 |pages=39–66 |year=2007 |bibcode=2007ICQ....29...39M}}</ref> Comets studied forward-scattering in [[Solar and Heliospheric Observatory|SOHO]] non-thermal C3 [[coronograph]] photometry include [[96P/Machholz]] and C/2004 F4 (Bradfield).<ref name=Marcus2007/> The brightness of the [[great comet]]s [[C/2006 P1]] (McNaught) and [[Comet Skjellerup–Maristany]] near [[perihelion]] were enhanced by forward scattering.<ref name="fscat">{{Cite journal |url = http://www.icq.eps.harvard.edu/marcus_icq29_119.pdf |bibcode = 2007ICQ....29..119M |title = Forward-Scattering Enhancement of Comet Brightness. II. The Light Curve of C/2006 P1 |journal = International Comet Quarterly |volume = 29 |first = Joseph N. |last = Marcus |date = October 2007 |publisher = International Comet Quarterly |pages = 119–130 |format = PDF |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110708051321/http://www.icq.eps.harvard.edu/marcus_icq29_119.pdf |archivedate = 2011-07-08 |df = }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{FS1037C}}
== External links == *[http://www2.jpl.nasa.gov/basics/saturn/ Cassini's Views of Saturn's Rings] *[http://spacecraftkits.com/scatter/ Light Scattering Demonstration]
[[Category:Radio frequency propagation]] [[Category:Scattering, absorption and radiative transfer (optics)]]

revision.text:
[[File:Turbogenerator01.jpg|thumb|right|A power plant turbo generator]] [[File:Turbinenhalle KSP.jpg|thumb|right|A power plant turbo generator; the yellow cylinder is the [[electrical generator]], the blue device is the [[steam turbine]], the yellow rectangular object in front is the excitation generator]] A '''hydrogen-cooled turbo generator''' is a [[turbo generator]] with [[gaseous hydrogen]] as a [[coolant]]. Hydrogen-cooled turbo generators are designed to provide a low-[[drag (physics)|drag]] atmosphere and cooling for single-shaft and [[combined-cycle]] applications in combination with [[steam turbine]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpls/abs_all.jsp?arnumber=1043376|title=Development of world's largest hydrogen-cooled turbine generator|first1=S.|last1=Nagano|first2=T.|last2=Kitajima|first3=K.|last3=Yoshida|first4=Y.|last4=Kazao|first5=Y.|last5=Kabata|first6=D.|last6=Murata|first7=K.|last7=Nagakura|date=1 July 2002|publisher=|volume=2|pages=657–663 vol.2|via=IEEE Xplore|doi=10.1109/PESS.2002.1043376}}</ref> Because of the high [[thermal conductivity]] and other favorable properties of hydrogen gas this is the most common type in its field today.
==History== Based on the air-cooled turbo generator, gaseous [[hydrogen]] first went into service as the [[coolant]] in a hydrogen-cooled turbo generator in October 1937, at the [[Dayton Power & Light]] Co. in [[Dayton, Ohio]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/chronologicalhis00natirich/chronologicalhis00natirich_djvu.txt|title=Full text of "A chronological history of electrical development from 600 B.C."|publisher=}}</ref>
==Design== The use of gaseous hydrogen as a coolant is based on its properties, namely low [[density]], high [[Specific heat capacity|specific heat]], and the highest [[thermal conductivity]] (at 0.168 W/(m·K)) of all gases; it is 7-10 times better at cooling than air.<ref name=HydrogenCoolsWell>{{cite web|url=http://www.power-eng.com/articles/print/volume-113/issue-6/features/hydrogen-cools-well-but-safety-is-crucial.html|title=Hydrogen Cools Well, but Safety is Crucial|publisher=[[Power Engineering]]|accessdate=8 October 2017|quote=hydrogen’s low density, high specific heat and thermal conductivity make it a superior coolant for this application ... Hydrogen has one of the best heat transfer properties of any gas, with a specific heat of 3.4 Btu/lb-F at standard conditions. On a mass basis, hydrogen is 14 times more efficient than dry air for removing heat ... Hydrogen, as the lightest gas, has the lowest density of any stable gas. Wind resistance losses are kept to a minimum because the rotor’s wind resistance in a hydrogen-cooled generator is far less than in a similarly sized air-cooled generator }}</ref> Another advantage of hydrogen is its easy detection by [[hydrogen sensor]]s. A hydrogen-cooled generator can be significantly smaller, and therefore less expensive, than an air-cooled one. For stator cooling, water can be used.
[[Helium]] with a thermal-conductivity of 0.142 W/(m·K) was considered as coolant as well, however its high cost hinders its adoption despite its non-flammability.<ref>http://www2.emersonprocess.com/siteadmincenter/PM%20Rosemount%20Analytical%20Documents/Gas_ADS_Hydro_Cooled_Generators_103-200_200803.pdf{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Generally, three cooling approaches are used. For generators up to 300 MW, [[air cooling]] can be used. Between 250-450 MW hydrogen cooling is employed. For the highest power generators, up to 1800 MW, hydrogen and [[water cooling]] is used; the rotor is hydrogen-cooled, the stator [[winding]]s are made of hollow copper tubes cooled with water circulating through them.
The generators produce [[high voltage]]; the choice of voltage depends on the tradeoff between demands of [[electrical insulation]] and handling high electric current. For generators up to 40 MVA, the voltage is 6.3 kV; large generators with power above 1000 MW generate voltages up to 27 kV; voltages between 2.3-30 kV are used depending on the size of the generator. The generated power is sent to a nearby [[Step up transformer|step-up transformer]], where it is converted to the [[electric power transmission]] line voltage (typically between 115 and 1200 kV).
To control the [[centrifugal force]]s at high rotational speeds, the rotor diameter typically does not exceed 1.25 meters; the required large size of the coils is achieved by their length and so the generator is mounted horizontally. Two-pole machines typically operate at 3000 rpm for 50 Hz and 3600 rpm for 60 Hz systems, half of that for four-pole machines.
The turbogenerator also contains a smaller generator producing [[direct current]] [[Electric generator#Self-excitation|excitation power]] for the rotor coil. Older generators used [[dynamo]]s and [[slip ring]]s for DC injection to the rotor, but the moving mechanical contacts were subject to [[wear]]. Modern generators have the excitation generator on the same shaft as the turbine and main generator; the [[diode]]s needed are located directly on the rotor. The excitation current on larger generators can reach 10 kA. The amount of excitation power ranges between 0.5-3% of the generator output power.
The rotor usually contains caps or cage made of nonmagnetic material; its role is to provide a low impedance path for [[eddy current]]s which occur when the three phases of the generator are unevenly loaded. In such cases, eddy currents are generated in the rotor, and the resulting [[Joule heating]] could in extreme cases destroy the generator.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freepatentsonline.com/3898491.html|title=Damper winding for turbine generator rotors|publisher=}}</ref>
Hydrogen gas is circulated in a closed loop to remove [[heat]] from the active parts then it is cooled by gas-to-water [[heat exchanger]]s on the [[stator]] frame. The working pressure is up to 6 [[Bar (unit)|bar]].
An on-line [[thermal conductivity detector]] (TCD) analyzer is used with three measuring ranges. The first range (80-100% H<sub>2</sub>) to monitor the [[hydrogen purity]] during normal operation. The second (0-100% H<sub>2</sub>) and third (0-100% CO<sub>2</sub>) measuring ranges allow safe opening of the turbines for maintenance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.thomasnet.com/fullstory/487684|title=Gas Analyzer constantly monitors hydrogen purity.|publisher=}}</ref>
Hydrogen has very low [[viscosity]], a favorable property for reducing [[drag (physics)|drag]] losses in the rotor; these losses can be significant, as the rotors have large diameter and high rotational speed. Every reduction in the purity of the hydrogen coolant increases [[windage]] losses in the turbine; as air is 14 times more dense than hydrogen, each 1% of air corresponds to about 14% increase of density of the coolant and the associated increase of viscosity and drag. A purity drop from 97 to 95% in a large generator can increase windage losses by 32%; this equals to 685 kW for a 907 MW generator.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gesensing.com/products/resources/application_notes/930_087A.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081116181811/http://www.gesensing.com/products/resources/application_notes/930_087A.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2008-11-16|publisher=}}</ref> The windage losses also increase heat losses of the generator and the associated cooling problems.<ref>http://protonenergy.com/backend/arc_contenido/archivo117.pdf{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Operation==
The absence of [[oxygen]] in the atmosphere within significantly reduces the damage of the windings insulation by eventual [[corona discharge]]s; these can be problematic as the generators typically operate at [[high voltage]], often 20 kV.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gepower.com/prod_serv/products/generators/en/hydrogen_cool.htm|title=Gas Turbines - GE Power Generation|publisher=}}</ref>
===Seal oil system=== The [[bearing (mechanical)|bearings]] have to be leak-tight. A [[hermetic seal]], usually a [[liquid seal]], is employed; a [[turbine oil]] at pressure higher than the hydrogen inside is typically used. A metal, e.g. [[brass]], ring is pressed by [[spring (device)|springs]] onto the generator shaft, the oil is forced under pressure between the ring and the shaft; part of the oil flows into the hydrogen side of the generator, another part to the air side. The oil entrains a small amount of air; as the oil is recirculated, some of the air is carried over into the generator. This causes a gradual air contamination buildup and requires maintaining hydrogen purity. Scavenging systems are used for this purpose; gas (mixture of entrained air and hydrogen, released from the oil) is collected in the holding tank for the sealing oil, and released into the atmosphere; the hydrogen losses have to be replenished, either from [[gas cylinder]]s or from on-site hydrogen generators. Degradation of bearings leads to higher oil leaks, which increases the amount of air transferred into the generator. Increased oil consumption can be detected by a [[flow meter]] for each bearing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.control.com/thread/1267097548|title=Generator Hydrogen Cooling System|publisher=}}</ref>
===Drying=== Presence of [[water]] in hydrogen has to be avoided, as it causes deterioration of hydrogen's cooling properties, [[corrosion]] of the generator parts, [[electric arc|arcing]] in the high voltage windings, and reduces the lifetime of the generator. A [[desiccant]]-based dryer is usually included in the gas circulation loop, typically with a moisture probe in the dryer's outlet, sometimes also in its inlet. Presence of moisture is also indirect evidence of air leaking into the generator compartment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gesensing.com/downloads/hygrometers/downloads/910-170B1.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060315034852/http://www.gesensing.com/downloads/hygrometers/downloads/910-170B1.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2006-03-15}}</ref> Another option is optimizing the hydrogen scavenging, so the [[dew point]] is kept within the generator's specifications. The water is usually introduced into the generator atmosphere as an impurity in the turbine oil; another route is via leaks in water cooling systems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.powergenworldwide.com/index/display/articledisplay/183731/articles/power-engineering/volume-107/issue-8/features/water-contamination-in-hydrogen-cooled-generators-lurks-as-serious-operational-threat.html|title=Water Contamination in Hydrogen-Cooled Generators Lurks as Serious Operational Threat|publisher=}}</ref>
===Purging=== The [[flammability limit]]s (4-75% of hydrogen in air at normal temperature, wider at high temperatures<ref>http://www1.eere.energy.gov/hydrogenandfuelcells/tech_validation/pdfs/fcm01r0.pdf</ref>), its [[autoignition temperature]] at 571 °C, its very low [[minimum ignition energy]], and its tendency to form explosive mixtures with air, require provisions to be made for maintaining the hydrogen content within the generator above the upper or below the lower flammability limit at all times, and other [[hydrogen safety]] measures. When filled with hydrogen, overpressure has to be maintained as inflow of air into the generator could cause a dangerous [[explosion]] in its confined space. The generator enclosure is purged before opening it for maintenance, and before refilling the generator with hydrogen. During shutdown, hydrogen is purged by an inert gas, then the inert gas is replaced by air; the opposite sequence is used before startup. [[Carbon dioxide]] or [[nitrogen]] can be used for this purpose, as they do not form combustible mixtures with hydrogen and are inexpensive. Gas purity sensors are used to indicate the end of the purging cycle, which shortens the startup and shutdown times and reduces consumption of the purging gas. Carbon dioxide is favored as due to the very high density difference it easily displaces the hydrogen. The carbon dioxide is admitted to the bottom of the generator first, pushing the hydrogen out at the top. Then air is admitted to the top, pushing the carbon dioxide out at the bottom. Purging is best done with the generator stopped. If done while on barring slow speed unloaded rotation, the generator fans will mix the gases and greatly increase the time required to achieve purity.
===Make-up=== Hydrogen is often produced on-site using a plant consisting of an array of [[Electrolysis of water|electrolysis]] cells, compressors and storage vessels. This reduces the need for storing [[compressed hydrogen]] and allows storage in lower pressure tanks, with associated safety benefits and lower costs. Some gaseous hydrogen has to be kept for refilling the generator but it can be also generated on-site.
As technology evolves materials not susceptible to [[hydrogen embrittlement]] are used in generator designs. Not doing so can lead to equipment failure from [[hydrogen embrittlement]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://h2incidents.org/incident.asp?inc=102&cat=2&val=10|title=Lessons Learned - Hydrogen Tools|publisher=}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Timeline of hydrogen technologies]] *[[Precooled jet engine]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100821180100/http://www.labplan.ufsc.br/congressos/PowerTech07/papers/664.pdf The turbogenerator – A continuous engineering challenge]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hydrogen-Cooled Turbogenerator}} [[Category:Turbines]] [[Category:Electric power]] [[Category:Hydrogen technologies]]
[[de:Turbogenerator#Kühlung]]

revision.comment: Adding 0 [[arXiv|arxiv eprint(s)]], 3 [[bibcode|bibcode(s)]] and 0 [[digital object identifier|doi(s)]]. Did it miss something? Report bugs, errors, and suggestions at [[User talk:Bibcode Bot]]
revision.text:
The '''iris hypothesis''' is a hypothesis proposed by [[Richard Lindzen]] et al. in 2001 that suggested increased [[sea surface temperature]] in the [[tropics]] would result in reduced [[cirrus cloud]]s and thus more [[infrared radiation]] leakage from [[Earth]]'s [[atmosphere]]. His study of observed changes in cloud coverage and modeled effects on infrared radiation released to space as a result supported the hypothesis.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://eaps.mit.edu/faculty/lindzen/adinfriris.pdf |author=Lindzen, R.S., M.-D. Chou, and A.Y. Hou |year=2001 |title=Does the Earth have an adaptive infrared iris? |journal=Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc. |volume=82 |pages=417–432 |doi=10.1175/1520-0477(2001)082<0417:DTEHAA>2.3.CO;2 |bibcode=2001BAMS...82..417L |issue=3}}</ref> This suggested infrared radiation leakage was hypothesized to be a [[negative feedback]] in which an initial warming would result in an overall cooling of the surface. The consensus view is that increased sea surface temperature would result in increased cirrus clouds and reduced infrared radiation leakage and therefore a positive feedback.
Other scientists subsequently tested the hypothesis. Some concluded that there was no evidence supporting the hypothesis.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/pdf/10.1175/1520-0477%282002%29083%3C0249%3ANEFI%3E2.3.CO%3B2 |author1=Hartman, D.L. |author2=M.L. Michelsen |year=2002 |title=No evidence for iris |journal=Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc. |volume=83 |pages=249–254 |doi=10.1175/1520-0477(2002)083<0249:NEFI>2.3.CO;2 |issue=2 |bibcode = 2002BAMS...83..249H }}</ref> Others found evidence suggesting that increased sea surface temperature in the tropics did indeed reduce [[cirrus cloud]]s but found that the effect was nonetheless a positive feedback rather than the negative feedback that Lindzen had hypothesized.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.5194/acp-2-31-2002 |url=http://www.atmos-chem-phys.net/2/31 |author=Fu, Q., Baker, M., and Hartman, D. L. |title=Tropical cirrus and water vapor: an effective Earth infrared iris feedback? |journal=Atmos. Chem. Phys. |volume=2 |issue=1 |pages=31–37 |year=2002 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=The Iris Hypothesis: A Negative or Positive Cloud Feedback? |author=Lin, B., B. Wielicki, L. Chambers, Y. Hu, and K.-M. Xu |journal=J. Clim. |volume=15 |issue=1 |pages=3–7 |doi=10.1175/1520-0442(2002)015<0003:TIHANO>2.0.CO;2 |year=2002 |bibcode=2002JCli...15....3L}}</ref>
A later 2007 study conducted by [[Roy Spencer (scientist)|Roy Spencer]] et al. using updated satellite data potentially supported the iris hypothesis.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.agu.org/pubs/crossref/2007/2007GL029698.shtml |author=Spencer, R.W., Braswell, W.D., Christy, J.R., Hnilo, J. |year=2007 |title=Cloud and radiation budget changes associated with tropical intraseasonal oscillations |journal=Geophys. Res. Lett. |volume=34 |pages=L15707 |doi=10.1029/2007GL029698 |bibcode=2007GeoRL..3415707S |issue=15}}</ref> In 2011, Lindzen published a rebuttal to the main criticisms.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Lindzen R.S. |author2=Y.-S. Choi |title=On the observational determination of climate sensitivity and its implications |journal=Asia-Pacific J. Atmos. Sci. |volume=47 |issue= |pages=377–390 |year=2011 |doi=10.1007/s13143-011-0023-x |url=http://www-eaps.mit.edu/faculty/lindzen/236-Lindzen-Choi-2011.pdf |format=PDF|bibcode=2011APJAS..47..377L }}</ref> In 2015 a paper was published which again suggested the possibility of an "Iris Effect".<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Mauritsen T. |author2=Stevens B. |title=Missing iris effect as a possible cause of muted hydrological change and high climate sensitivity in models |journal=Nature Geoscience |volume=8 |issue= |pages=346–351 |year=2015 |doi=10.1038/ngeo2414|bibcode=2015NatGe...8..346M}}</ref> It also proposed what it called a "plausible physical mechanism for an iris effect." In 2017 a paper was published which found that "tropical anvil cirrus clouds exert a negative climate feedback in strong association with precipitation efficiency"<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Choi|first=Yong-Sang|last2=Kim|first2=WonMoo|last3=Yeh|first3=Sang-Wook|last4=Masunaga|first4=Hirohiko|last5=Kwon|first5=Min-Jae|last6=Jo|first6=Hyun-Su|last7=Huang|first7=Lei|title=Revisiting the iris effect of tropical cirrus clouds with TRMM and A-Train satellite data|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/2016JD025827/abstract|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres|language=en|pages=2016JD025827|doi=10.1002/2016JD025827|issn=2169-8996|bibcode=2017JGRD..122.5917C}}</ref>. If confirmed then that finding would be highly supportive of the existence of an "Iris Effect".
== See also== *[[Global dimming]] *[[Global warming]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links== *[http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/Study/Iris/ NASA summary of Global Warming and Iris Hypothesis] (June 2002)
{{global warming}}
[[Category:Climatology]] [[Category:Climate change science]] [[Category:Climate feedbacks]]

revision.comment: Removing from [[Category:American women writers]] (parent category) using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2015}} {{no footnotes|date=August 2013}} {{ infobox writer | name = Janisse Ray | image = | imagesize = | alt = A smiling woman with slightly graying hair, in a maroon print blouse with a small string of pearls sits outside in front of a building. | caption = Ray in May 2010; Picture supplied by Janisse Ray | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1962|2|2}} | birth_place = [[Baxley, Georgia|Baxley]] [[Georgia (U.S. state)|GA]], USA | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = Professor, environmental activist | language = English | nationality = USA | ethnicity = | citizenship = USA | education = [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]], [[Florida State University|Florida State]], 1984; [[Master of Fine Arts|MFA]], [[University of Montana|Montana]], 1997 | alma_mater = | period = Contemporary | genre = memoirs | subject = nature | movement = | notableworks = ''Ecology of a Cracker Childhood'' | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | influences = | influenced = | awards = [[American Book Award]], Southern Book Critics Circle Award, Southern Environmental Law Center Award for Outstanding Writing on the Southern environment | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Janisse Ray''' (born 1962) is an American writer, [[naturalist]] and [[environmental activist]]. She was born on February 2 in [[Baxley, Georgia]], the daughter of Franklin D. and Lee Ada Branch Ray. She attended [[North Georgia College]], 1980–82; [[Florida State University]], [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]], 1984, and the [[University of Montana]], [[Master of Fine Arts|MFA]], 1997.
Her first book, ''Ecology of a Cracker Childhood,'' recounts her experiences growing up in a junkyard, the daughter of a poor, white, fundamentalist Christian family. The book interweaves family history and memoir with [[natural history]] writing—specifically, descriptions of the ecology of the vanishing [[longleaf pine]] forests that once blanketed much of [[Southern United States|the South]]. The book won the [[American Book Award]], the Southern Book Critics Circle Award and the Southern Environmental Law Center Award for Outstanding Writing on the Southern environment. It also was chosen for the "All Georgia Reading the Same Book" project by the Georgia Center for the Book.
Ray's second book, ''Wild Card Quilt,'' recounts her experiences of moving back home to [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] with her son after attending graduate school in [[Montana]].
Her third book, ''Pinhook'', tells the story of Pinhook Swamp, the land that connects the [[Okefenokee Swamp]] in Georgia and [[Osceola National Forest]] in Florida
Her fourth book, ''Drifting into Darien'', published in 2011, describes her experiences on and knowledge about the [[Altamaha River]], which runs from middle Georgia to the Atlantic Ocean at [[Darien, Georgia|Darien]].
Ray published a book of poetry, ''A House of Branches'', in 2010, and has been a contributor to ''[[Audubon (magazine)|Audubon]],'' ''[[Orion (magazine)|Orion]]'' and other magazines, as well as a commentator for [[NPR]]'s ''[[Living on Earth]]''. An environmental activist, she has campaigned on behalf of the Altamaha River and the Moody Swamp.
She teaches in the [[Chatham University]] [[Low-residency program|Low-Residency]] [[Master of Fine Arts|Master of Fine Arts Program]] [[Creative Writing|in Creative Writing]].
She has a son, Silas Ausable, who attended the University of Massachusetts. As a student there he studied landscape architecture.
==Books==
* ''Ecology of a Cracker Childhood'', memoir (Minneapolis: Milkweed Editions, 2000). * ''Wild Card Quilt: Taking a Chance on Home'', memoir (Minneapolis: Milkweed Editions, 2003). * ''Between Two Rivers: Stories from the Red Hills to the Gulf'', (Co-editor, with Susan Cerulean and Laura Newtown) nonfiction (Tallahassee: Heart of the Earth, 2004). * ''Pinhook: Finding Wholeness in a Fragmented Land,'', nonfiction (White River Junction: Chelsea Green Publishing Company, 2005). * ''A House of Branches,'', poetry (Nicholasville: Wind Publications, 2010). * ''Drifting into Darien: a Personal and Natural History of the Altamaha River,'' nonfiction (Athens: The University of Georgia Press, 2011). * ''The Seed Underground: A Growing Revolution to Save Food,'' nonfiction (White River Junction: Chelsea Green Publishing Company, 2012).
==References== Source: Contemporary Authors Online. The Gale Group, 2005.
==External links== * [http://milkweed.org/shop/product/216 Milkweed Editions] webpage for ''Ecology of a Cracker Childhood'' * [http://windpub.com/books/branches.htm Wind Publications] webpage for ''House of Branches'' * [http://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/nge/Article.jsp?id=h-2562 Georgia Encyclopedia] entry for Janisse Ray * [http://www.wholeterrain.org/bio.cfm?Contributor_ID=305 Whole Terrain] link to Ray's articles published in [[Whole Terrain]] * Janisse Ray and Nancy Marshall, [http://southernspaces.org/2011/james-holland-riverkeeper-environmental-protection-along-altamaha "James Holland, Riverkeeper: Environmental Protection Along the Altamaha"], ''Southern Spaces'', August 11, 2011. * Janisse Ray, [http://southernspaces.org/2012/sowing-seed-underground "Sowing ''The Seed Underground''"], ''Southern Spaces'', October 23, 2012. {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ray, Janisse}} [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American naturalists]] [[Category:Chatham University faculty]] [[Category:People from Baxley, Georgia]] [[Category:Writers from Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:Women science writers]] [[Category:American Book Award winners]] [[Category:American nature writers]] [[Category:American women non-fiction writers]]

This is a '''list of NGC objects 1–1000''' from the [[New General Catalogue]] (NGC). The [[astronomical catalog]]ue is composed mainly of [[star cluster]]s, [[nebula]]e, and [[galaxies]]. Other objects in the catalogue can be found in the other subpages of the [[list of NGC objects]].
The constellation information in these tables is from ''The Complete New General Catalogue and Index Catalogue of Nebulae and Star Clusters by J. L. E. Dreyer'',<ref name="sinnott1988"> {{cite book |author=R. W. Sinnott, editor |title=The Complete New General Catalogue and Index Catalogue of Nebulae and Star Clusters by J. L. E. Dreyer |date=1988 |publisher=Sky Publishing Corporation and Cambridge University Press |isbn=0-933346-51-4 }}</ref> which was accessed using the VizieR Service.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://vizier.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/VizieR |title=VizieR Service |work=Strasbourg astronomical Data Center |accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref> Galaxy morphological types and objects that are members of the [[Small Magellanic Cloud]] are identified using the ''NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/ |title=NED |work=NED–NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database |accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref> The other data of these tables are from the [[SIMBAD Astronomical Database]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/ |title=SIMBAD Astronomical Database |work=Strasbourg astronomical Data Center |accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref> unless otherwise stated.

page.title: List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Cambridgeshire

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9) ([[User:FA RotBot|FA RotBot]])
revision.text:
{{about|SSSIs in Cambridgeshire|other counties|List of SSSIs by Area of Search}} [[File:Ouse Washes at Welney - geograph.org.uk - 1046140.jpg|right|350px|thumb|[[Ouse Washes]] at [[Welney]]]] [[Cambridgeshire]] is a county in eastern England, with an area of {{convert|339,746|ha|sqmi|0}}{{cite web |title=Standard Area Measurements (2016) for Administrative Areas in the United Kingdom |url=http://ons.maps.arcgis.com/home/item.html?id=a79de233ad254a6d9f76298e666abb2b |publisher=Office for National Statistics |accessdate=10 April 2017 |df= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170410214852/http://ons.maps.arcgis.com/home/item.html?id=a79de233ad254a6d9f76298e666abb2b |archivedate=10 April 2017 }} and a population as of mid-2015 of 841,218.{{cite web|url=https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/populationestimates/datasets/populationestimatesforukenglandandwalesscotlandandnorthernireland |title=Population Estimates for UK, England and Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland |publisher=Office for National Statistics |accessdate=10 April 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215062115/https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/populationestimates/datasets/populationestimatesforukenglandandwalesscotlandandnorthernireland |archivedate=15 February 2017 |df= }} It is crossed by the [[River Nene|Nene]] and the [[River Great Ouse|Great Ouse]] rivers. The [[University of Cambridge]], which was founded in the thirteenth century, made the county one of the country's most important intellectual centres. A large part of the county is in [[The Fens]], and drainage of this habitat, which probably commenced in the Roman period and was largely completed by the seventeenth century, considerably increased the area available for agriculture. The main manufacturing area is [[Peterborough]].{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Cambridgeshire |title=Cambridgeshire |publisher=Encyclopedia Britannica |year=2013 |accessdate=17 January 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161011224415/https://www.britannica.com/place/Cambridgeshire |archivedate=11 October 2016 |df= }} The administrative county was formed in 1974, incorporating most of the historic county of [[Huntingdonshire]]. Local government is divided between [[Cambridgeshire County Council]] and [[Peterborough City Council]], which is a separate [[Unitary authorities of England|unitary authority]]. Under the county council, there are five district councils, [[Cambridge City Council]], [[South Cambridgeshire District Council]], [[East Cambridgeshire District Council]], [[Huntingdonshire District Council]] and [[Fenland District Council]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk/info/20050/council_structure/81/local_government_in_cambridgeshire |title=Local government in Cambridgeshire |publisher=Cambridgeshire County Council |accessdate=25 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160819221806/http://www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk/info/20050/council_structure/81/local_government_in_cambridgeshire |archivedate=19 August 2016 |df= }} In England, [[Site of Special Scientific Interest|Sites of Special Scientific Interest]] (SSSIs) are designated by [[Natural England]], which is responsible for protecting England's natural environment. Designation as an SSSI gives legal protection to the most important wildlife and geological sites.{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/sites-of-special-scientific-interest-designation |publisher=Natural England |title=Sites of Special Scientific Interest: Designation |accessdate=19 April 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306231551/https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/sites-of-special-scientific-interest-designation |archivedate= 6 March 2016 |df= }} As of March 2017, there are 99 sites designated in the county.{{cite web|title=Designated Sites View: Cambridgeshire|publisher =Natural England|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteList.aspx?siteName=&countyCode=4&responsiblePerson=|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|accessdate=5 March 2017}} There are eighty-eight sites listed for their biological interest, ten for their geological interest, and one for both interests. The largest site is [[Ouse Washes]] at {{convert|2,513.6| ha|acres}}, which is partly in Norfolk. It is internationally important for its wintering and breeding waterfowl and waders, such as [[Anas crecca|teal]], [[Anas acuta|pintail]] and [[Anas penelope|wigeon]]. The smallest is [[Delph Bridge Drain]] at {{convert|0.1|ha|acres}}, a short stretch of ditch which was designated because it was found to have a population of [[fen ragwort]], which was believed to have been extinct in Britain since 1857. The only site designated for both biological and geological interests is [[Ely Pits and Meadows]], which has nationally important numbers of [[Botaurus stellaris|bitterns]], and has yielded [[sauropod]] [[dinosaur]]s and [[pliosaur]] marine reptiles dating to the [[Jurassic]] period. ==Key== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ===Interest=== *'''B''' = a site of biological interest *'''G''' = a site of geological interest ===Public access=== *'''FP''' = access to footpaths through the site only *'''NO''' = no public access to site *'''PP''' = public access to part of site *'''WTPR''' = Wildlife Trust permit required for access *'''YES''' = public access to the whole or most of the site {{col-2}} ===Other classifications=== *'''GCR''' = [[Geological Conservation Review]] *'''LNR''' = [[Local Nature Reserve]] *'''NCR''' = [[A Nature Conservation Review]] *'''NNR''' = [[National Nature Reserve (United Kingdom)|National Nature Reserve]] *'''NT''' = [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]] *'''Ramsar''' = [[Ramsar site]], an internationally important wetland site *'''RSPB''' = [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] *'''SAC''' = [[Special Area of Conservation]] *'''SM''' = [[Scheduled Monument]] *'''SPA''' = [[Special Protection Area]] *'''WT''' = [[Woodland Trust]] *'''WTBCN''' = [[Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire]] *'''WWT''' = [[Wildfowl & Wetlands Trust]] {{col-end}} {{kml}} ==Sites== {{Compact ToC|side=yes|i=|j=|q=|v=|x=|y=|z=}} {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" ! scope="col" | Site name ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Photograph ! scope="col" |{{tooltip|B|Site of biological interest}} ! scope="col" |{{tooltip|G|Site of geological interest}} ! scope="col" | Area ! scope="col" | Public
access ! scope="col" | Location ! scope="col" |Other
classifications ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Map{{efn|The maps are provided by Natural England on the ''Magic Map'' website.}} ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Citation{{efn|Citations are provided for each site by Natural England.}} ! scope="col" class="unsortable" |Description |- ! scope="row"|{{Anchor|A}}[[Adventurers' Land]] |[[File:Adventurers' Land and Guyhirn Wash.jpg|100px|alt=Adventurers' Land]] | | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 10.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1005502&SiteName=adventurers&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Adventurers' Land | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 25 November 2016}} | align="center"|YES | [[March, Cambridgeshire|March]]
{{coord| 52.598|0.008 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Adventurers' Land }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TF361019 }} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2527 |title=Adventurers' Land (Quaternary of East Anglia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=4 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220061229/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2527 |archivedate=20 December 2016 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1005502}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005502.pdf Citation] |The site is described by [[Natural England]] as important for the study of changes in [[Holocene]] sea levels. There are five peat levels dating to between 6,400 and 1,850 years [[Before Present|BP]], and the earliest level represents the oldest directly dated transgression of the sea into the [[Fens]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005502.pdf |title=Adventurers' Land citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304034350/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005502.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Alder Carr]] |[[File:Alder Carr 4.jpg|100px|alt=Alder Carr]] |align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 6.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003973&SiteName=alder&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Alder Carr |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=4 September 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160915184136/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003973&SiteName=alder&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |archivedate=15 September 2016 |df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[Hildersham]]
{{coord|52.117|0.251 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Alder Carr }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL542489 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1003973}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003973.pdf Citation] |The site is a wet valley which has alder on fen peat, a type of woodland which is now rare in [[East Anglia]]. Ground flora include [[Angelica sylvestris|angelica]] and [[meadowsweet]]. This habitat is very valuable to invertebrates.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003973.pdf |title=Alder Carr citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=4 September 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304030732/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003973.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Aversley Wood]] |[[File:Pond in the heart of Aversley Wood - geograph.org.uk - 1516268.jpg|100px|alt=Aversley Wood]] |align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 62.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000002&SiteName=aversley&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Aversley Wood |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161129023643/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000002&SiteName=aversley&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |archivedate=29 November 2016 |df= }} | align="center"|YES | [[Sawtry]]
{{coord|52.423|-0.294 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Aversley Wood}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL161819 }} |[[Woodland Trust|WT]]{{cite web|url=https://www.woodlandtrust.org.uk/visiting-woods/wood/?woodId=4031&woodName=aversley-wood |title=Aversley Wood |publisher=Woodland Trust |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161129024918/https://www.woodlandtrust.org.uk/visiting-woods/wood/?woodId=4031&woodName=aversley-wood |archivedate=29 November 2016 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1000002}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000002.pdf Citation] |This wood is ash and maple on heavy clay soils, with much of it dating to before the [[Middle Ages]], and having diverse flora and fauna as a result. One area, which was probably cultivated until around 1350, has medieval [[ridge and furrow]] and lacks some plants found in areas which have been more continuously forested.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000002.pdf |title=Aversley Wood citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304040350/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000002.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|{{Anchor|B}}[[Balsham Wood]] |[[File:Balsham Wood 1.jpg|100px|alt=Balsham Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 35.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000028&SiteName=balsham&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Balsham Wood |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=4 September 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160915183102/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000028&SiteName=balsham&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |archivedate=15 September 2016 |df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[Balsham]]

There are several nationally uncommon beetles, such as the [[rove beetle]] ''[[Stichoglossa semirufa]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000848.pdf |title=Elsworth Wood citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=27 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304064516/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000848.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Ely Pits and Meadows]] |[[File:Roswell Pits.jpg|100px|alt=Ely Pits]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert|85.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000642&SiteName=ely&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Ely Pits and Meadows |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=1 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161202170110/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000642&SiteName=ely&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |archivedate= 2 December 2016 |df= }} | align="center"|PP | [[Ely, Cambridgeshire|Ely]]

{{gbmappingsmall| TL554808}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web|url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1156 |title=Roswell Pits, Ely (Jurassic - Cretaceous Reptilia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=1 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161202040638/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1156 |archivedate= 2 December 2016 |df= }} [[Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire|WTBCN]]{{cite web |url=http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/roswell-pits |title=Roswell Pits |publisher=Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire |accessdate=1 December 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160817125851/http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/roswell-pits |archivedate=17 August 2016 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|2000642}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000642.pdf Citation] |This site has yielded an extensive assemblage of fossil reptiles dating to the [[Kimmeridgian]], around 155 million years ago in the late [[Jurassic]]. Its biological interest lies mainly in its breeding birds, especially nationally rare wintering and breeding [[Botaurus stellaris|bitterns]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000642.pdf |title=Ely Pits and Meadows citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=1 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304045340/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000642.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Eversden and Wimpole Woods]] |[[File:Eversden Wood - geograph.org.uk - 395637.jpg|100px|alt=Eversden Wood]] |align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 66.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000416&SiteName=eversden&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Eversden and Wimpole Woods | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 5 December 2016}} | align="center"|YES | [[Great Eversden]]
{{coord|52.16|-0.035 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Eversden and Wimpole Woods }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL345531 }} |[[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]]{{cite web|url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/ProtectedSites/SACselection/sac.asp?EUCode=UK0030331 |title=Eversden and Wimpole Woods SAC |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=2 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160321040528/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/ProtectedSites/SACselection/sac.asp?EUCode=UK0030331 |archivedate=21 March 2016 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1000416}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000416.pdf Citation] |Wimpole Wood has six bat species, including the [[barbastelle]], which is a very rare species in Britain; females give birth and raise young in tree crevices. Eversden Wood is a species rich example of a type of woodland rare in lowland Britain, with ancient ash and field maple trees.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000416.pdf |title=Eversden and Wimpole Woods citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=5 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303225253/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000416.pdf |archivedate= 3 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Eye Gravel Pit]] |[[File:Eye Gravel Pit 2.jpg|100px|alt=Eye Gravel Pit]] | | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 0.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000439&SiteName=eye&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Eye Gravel Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=9 October 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161010125122/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000439&SiteName=eye&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |archivedate=10 October 2016 |df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[Eye Green]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TF230036 }} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2009 |title= Eye Gravel Pit (Quaternary of East Anglia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 9 October 2016}} |{{Nature on the map|1000439}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000439.pdf Citation] |This former gravel quarry has marine and a few non-marine shells laid down when the area was under the [[North Sea]], probably during the warm [[Eemian]] period, 130,000 to 115,000 years ago.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000439.pdf |title=Eye Gravel Pit citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=9 October 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304061741/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000439.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|{{Anchor|F}}[[Fleam Dyke]] |[[File:Fleam Dyke looking NW - geograph.org.uk - 1017317.jpg|100px|alt=Fleam Dyke]] |align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 11.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001069&SiteName=fleam&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Fleam Dyke | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 6 December 2016}} | align="center"|YES | [[Fulbourn]]
{{coord|52.16|0.266 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Fleam Dyke }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL551539}} |[[Scheduled monument|SM]]{{cite web|url=https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1006931 |title=Fleam Dyke |publisher=Historic England |accessdate=2 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161203000703/https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1006931 |archivedate= 3 December 2016 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1001069}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001069.pdf Citation] |Fleam Dyke is one of 286 sites selected by [[Charles Rothschild]] between 1912 and 1915 as wildlife sites "worthy of preservation" in Britain and Ireland.{{cite web |url=http://www.wildlifetrusts.org/aboutthearchive |title=The Rothschild Reserves: About the Archive |publisher=The Wildlife Trusts |accessdate=6 December 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120818023315/http://www.wildlifetrusts.org/aboutthearchive |archivedate=18 August 2012 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://www.wildlifetrusts.org/who-we-are/history/rothschild-reserves/fleam-dyke-cambridgeshire |title=The Rothschild Reserves: Fleam Dyke |publisher=The Wildlife Trusts |accessdate=6 December 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160826022540/http://www.wildlifetrusts.org/who-we-are/history/rothschild-reserves/fleam-dyke-cambridgeshire |archivedate=26 August 2016 |df=dmy-all }} The steep banks of the earthwork have species-rich chalk grassland, a rare habitat in the county.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001069.pdf |title=Fleam Dyke citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=6 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303235906/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001069.pdf |archivedate= 3 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! Herbs in drier areas include [[Primula veris|cowslip]] and [[salad burnet]], while wetter areas have tall fen vegetation.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001093.pdf |title=Fulbourn Fen citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=6 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304072806/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001093.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Furze Hill SSSI|Furze Hill]] |[[File:Furze Hill 1.jpg|100px|alt=Furze Hill]] |align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 5.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001115&SiteName=furze&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Furze Hill |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=4 September 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160915190949/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001115&SiteName=furze&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |archivedate=15 September 2016 |df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[Hildersham]]

There are several rare plants, such as [[Potentilla argentea|hoary cinquefoil]]s, [[Pulsatilla vulgaris|pasque flowers]] and [[maiden pink]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001115.pdf |title=Furze Hill citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=4 September 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304053003/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001115.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|{{Anchor|G}}[[Gamlingay Wood]] |[[File:Gamlingay Wood 6.jpg|100px|alt=Gamlingay Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 48.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001138&SiteName=gamlingay&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Gamlingay Wood | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 30 January 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Gamlingay]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TL242534 }} |[[WTBCN]]{{cite web|url=http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/gamlingay-wood |title=Gamlingay Wood |publisher=Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire |accessdate=6 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160728092813/http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/gamlingay-wood |archivedate=28 July 2016 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1001138}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001138.pdf Citation] |This is ancient ash/maple woodland on sandy loam soil, an unusual habitat in lowland England. Ground flora include [[dog's mercury]], [[yellow archangel]], [[Anemone nemorosa|wood anemone]] and the nationally restricted [[oxlip]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001138.pdf |title=Gamlingay Wood citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=30 January 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304075850/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001138.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} The flora is diverse due to the varied soils, and there are hundreds of species of mushrooms and toadstools.{{cite web |url=http://live.data.wt.precedenthost.co.uk/sites/default/files/Gaml-Sug%20Wood%20lflt%202011.pdf |title=Welcome to Gamlingay and Sugley Wood |publisher=Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire |accessdate=30 January 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202050543/http://live.data.wt.precedenthost.co.uk/sites/default/files/Gaml-Sug%20Wood%20lflt%202011.pdf |archivedate=2 February 2017 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Godmanchester Eastside Common]] |[[File:Godmanchester Eastside Common 4.jpg|100px|alt=Godmanchester Eastside Common]] |align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 29.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004017&SiteName=godmanchester&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Godmanchester Eastside Common | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 13 September 2016}} | align="center"|YES | [[Godmanchester]]

The southern field has lines of medieval [[ridge and furrow]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004017.pdf |title=Godmanchester Eastside Common citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=13 September 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304030003/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004017.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Gog Magog Golf Course]] |[[File:Gog Magog Golf Club.jpg|100px|alt=Gog Magog Golf Course]] |align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 88.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002554&SiteName=gog&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Gog Magog Golf Course |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=6 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220080008/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002554&SiteName=gog&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |archivedate=20 December 2016 |df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[Fulbourn]]

Locally uncommon flora include [[Astragalus danicus|purple milk-vetch]], [[felwort]], [[meadow saxifrage]], [[green-winged orchid]] and [[Trifolium ochroleucon|sulphur clover]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002271.pdf |title=Great Wilbraham Common citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304033457/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002271.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|{{Anchor|H}}[[Hardwick Wood]] |[[File:Hardwick Wood 7.jpg|100px|alt=Hardwick Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 15.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001164&SiteName=hardwick&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Hardwick Wood | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 1 October 2016}} | align="center"|YES | [[Caldecote, Cambridgeshire|Caldecote]]

A parish boundary fence is estimated to date from the eleventh century or earlier, and it has high wildlife value.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001237.pdf |title=Hayley Wood citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=30 January 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304001704/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001237.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://data.wildlifetrusts.org/sites/default/files/Hayley%20Wood%20-%20May%202012.pdf |title=Welcome to Hayley Wood |publisher=Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire |accessdate=30 January 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202083639/http://data.wildlifetrusts.org/sites/default/files/Hayley%20Wood%20-%20May%202012.pdf |archivedate= 2 February 2017 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Hemingford Grey Meadow]] |[[File:Hemingford Grey Meadow 2.jpg|100px|alt=Hemingford Grey Meadow]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 0.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004037&SiteName=hemingford&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Hemingford Grey Meadow | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 13 September 2016}} | align="center"|YES | [[Hemingford Grey]]

Wetland herbs include [[ragged robin]], [[Pulicaria dysenterica|fleabane]] and [[purple loosestrife]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002410.pdf |title=Thriplow Meadows citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=19 August 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304000525/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002410.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=sssiIndex&query=HYPERLINK%3D%271002410%27 |title=Map of Thriplow Meadows |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=19 August 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160827080619/http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=sssiIndex&query=HYPERLINK%3D%271002410%27 |archivedate=27 August 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Thriplow Peat Holes]] |[[File:Thriplow Peat Holes 2.jpg|100px|alt=Thriplow Peat Holes]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 12.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002433&SiteName=thriplow&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Thriplow Peat Holes |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 28 August 2016}} | align="center"|NO | [[Thriplow]]
{{coord|52.107|0.116 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Thriplow Peat Holes }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL450475 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1002433}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002433.pdf Citation] |The site has rare [[alder carr]] and fen habitats, enhanced by ditches and ponds, with a wide variety of invertebrates. The main vegetation is [[Alnus glutinosa|alder]], [[Fraxinus excelsior|ash]], [[Salix cinerea|willow]] and [[guelder rose]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002433.pdf |title=Thriplow Peat Holes citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=19 August 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303225030/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002433.pdf |archivedate= 3 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Traveller's Rest Pit]] |[[File:Traveller's Rest Pit 2.jpg|100px|alt=Traveller's Rest Pit]] | | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 2.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002443&SiteName=traveller&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Traveller's Rest Pit | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 26 October 2016}} | align="center"|NO | [[Cambridge]]
{{coord|52.218|0.09 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Traveller's Rest Pit}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL429598 }} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1315 |title=Travellers Rest Pit (Quaternary of East Anglia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=26 October 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161026232238/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1315 |archivedate=26 October 2016 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1002443}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002443.pdf Citation] |This is described by [[Natural England]] as an important site dating to the [[Anglian stage|Anglian]] ice age around 450,000 years ago. It also has the most extensive collection of [[paleolithic]] stone tools in the county, which are thought to date to the [[Cromerian Stage]], which preceded the Anglian.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002443.pdf |title=Traveller's Rest Pit citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=26 October 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304070238/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002443.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }}{{cite web |url=https://www.scambs.gov.uk/sites/default/files/documents/Environment%20Statement%20Appendix%2069.pdf |page=12 |date=August 2011 |title=Traveller's Rest Pit baseline Report |publisher=University of Cambridge |accessdate=26 October 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161026233528/https://www.scambs.gov.uk/sites/default/files/documents/Environment%20Statement%20Appendix%2069.pdf |archivedate=2016-10-26 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|{{Anchor|U}}[[Upware Bridge Pit North]] |[[File:Upware Bridge Pit North 2.jpg|100px|alt=Upware Bridge Pit North]] | | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 2.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003308&SiteName=upware&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Upware Bridge Pit North |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=6 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161107155330/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003308&SiteName=upware&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |archivedate= 7 November 2016 |df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[Wicken, Cambridgeshire|Wicken]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TL543725}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2100 |title=Dimmock's Cote Quarry (Upware) (Oxfordian) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=6 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161107155249/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2100 |archivedate= 7 November 2016 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1003308}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003308.pdf Citation] |This site shows exposes rocks of [[Oxfordian (stage)|Oxfordian]] age, around 160 million years ago. It was then a sea which was connected to the [[Tethys Ocean]], and it has many Tethyan invertebrate fossils. It is described by [[Natural England]] as "an essential site for the study of Oxfordian palaeontology and palaeogeography in the English midlands".{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003308.pdf |title=Upware Bridge Pit North citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=6 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304031618/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003308.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Upware North Pit]] |[[File:Upware North Pit 1.jpg|100px|alt=Upware North Pit]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 1.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002481&SiteName=upware&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Upware North Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=9 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161110043637/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002481&SiteName=upware&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |archivedate=10 November 2016 |df= }} | align="center"|YES | [[Wicken, Cambridgeshire|Wicken]]
{{coord|52.331|0.264 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Upware North Pit}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL544727 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1002481}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002481.pdf Citation] |This site has several flooded pits with areas of willow and hawthorn. It is one of only two British sites which has [[Teucrium scordium|water germander]], a plant listed in the British [[Regional Red List#British reviews of conservation status|Red List of Threatened Species]]. Other unusual aquatic plants are [[great water dock]] and [[greater pond sedge]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002481.pdf |title=Upware North Pit citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=9 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303225522/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002481.pdf |archivedate= 3 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Upware South Pit]] |[[File:Upware South Pit 5.jpg|100px|alt=Upware South Pit]] | | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 1.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003122&SiteName=upware&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Upware South Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=9 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161109221717/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003122&SiteName=upware&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |archivedate= 9 November 2016 |df= }} | align="center"|YES | [[Upware]]
{{coord| 52.315|0.256|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Upware South Pit}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL539709}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2825 |title=Upware South Pit (Oxfordian) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=6 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161107155345/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2825 |archivedate= 7 November 2016 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1003122}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003122.pdf Citation] |This site has rocks dating to the [[Oxfordian (stage)|Oxfordian]] [[Stage (stratigraphy)|stage]], around 160 million years ago. It was then a [[coral reef]], and has fossils of [[bivalves]] and [[ammonites]], as well as corals, which show affinities with the fauna of the [[Tethys Ocean]]. It is described by [[Natural England]] as a key site in study of the Oxfordian.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003122.pdf |title=Upware South Pit citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=9 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304073034/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003122.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Upwood Meadows]] |[[File:Bentley Meadow, Upwood Meadows - geograph.org.uk - 839654.jpg|100px|alt=Upwood Meadows]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 6.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001681&SiteName=upwood&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Upwood Meadows | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 21 November 2016}} | align="center"|YES | [[Upwood]]

{{gbmappingsmall| TL251826}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, ''A Nature Conservation Review'', p. 139 [[National nature reserve (United Kingdom)|NNR]], [[WTBCN]]{{cite web |url=http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/upwood-meadows |title=Upwood Meadows |publisher=Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire |accessdate=21 November 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160318234053/http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/upwood-meadows |archivedate=18 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }} |{{Nature on the map|1001681}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001681.pdf Citation] |The site has three fields on calcareous clay with poor drainage, a type of pasture now very rare, and was described by [[Derek Ratcliffe]] as having "an outstandingly rich and diverse flora".
