{{gbmappingsmall|TL226540 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1003181}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003181.pdf Citation] |This site has an unusually varied geology, with areas of free-draining [[Lower Greensand Group|Lower Greensand]], poorly drained boulder clay and [[Jurassic]] clays. The wood is of ancient origin, and tree species include [[pedunculate oak]] and [[coppiced]] [[Fraxinus excelsior|ash]] and [[field maple]]. [[Corylus avellana|Hazel]] is dominant in the shrub layer. There are uncommon flowers such as [[herb-paris]], [[Platanthera chlorantha|butterfly orchid]] and [[Conopodium majus|pignut]].{{cite web|url= https://necmsi.esdm.co.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003181.pdf|title= Weaveley and Sand Woods citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 30 January 2017}}{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} |- ! scope="row"|[[West, Abbot's and Lound Woods]] |[[File:West, Abbot's and Lound Woods 7.jpg|100px|alt=West, Abbot's and Lound Woods]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 50.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003851&SiteName=lound&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: West, Abbot's and Lound Woods |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=28 August 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160911035146/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003851&SiteName=lound&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |archivedate=11 September 2016 |df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[Wittering, Cambridgeshire|Wittering]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TF043036 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1003241}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003241.pdf Citation] |Habitats in this site include a stream together with associated marsh, tall fen and willow [[Carr (landform)|carr]]. The carr has a varied flora, and the marsh has many plants rare in the county. There are also springs, which have mosses including the uncommon ''[[cratoneuron commutatum]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003241.pdf |title=Whitewater Valley citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=30 August 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304070623/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003241.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Whittlesford - Thriplow Hummocky Fields]] |[[File:Whittlesford-Thriplow Hummocky Fields 3.jpg|100px]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 55.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000877&SiteName=thriplow&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Whittlesford - Thriplow Hummocky Fields|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 28 August 2016}} | align="center"|NO | [[Whittlesford]]
{{coord| 52.115|0.112|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Whittlesford - Thriplow Hummocky Fields }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL447484 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1000877}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000877.pdf Citation] |This site has the nationally rare [[grass-poly]], and the nationally uncommon [[fairy shrimp]] ''[[chirocephalus diaphanus]]''. They are found in shallow hollows in arable fields, which are the result of [[ice lens]]es melting at the end of the [[Younger Dryas|last ice age]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000877.pdf |title=Whittlesford - Thriplow Hummocky Fields citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=19 August 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304033452/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000877.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Wicken Fen]] |[[File:Sedge Fen Drove, Wicken Fen - geograph.org.uk - 1760046.jpg|100px|alt=Wicken Fen]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 255.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003251&SiteName=wicken&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Wicken Fen | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 13 December 2016}} | align="center"|YES | [[Wicken, Cambridgeshire|Wicken]]
{{coord|52.307|0.278 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Wicken Fen}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL554701}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, ''A Nature Conservation Review'', p. 212 [[National nature reserve (United Kingdom)|NNR]], [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|NT]],{{cite web|url=https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/wicken-fen-nature-reserve |title=Wicken Fen Nature Reserve |publisher=National Trust |accessdate=13 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161025012714/https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/wicken-fen-nature-reserve |archivedate=25 October 2016 |df= }} [[Ramsar site|Ramsar]],{{cite web|url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/pdf/RIS/UK11077.pdf |title=Information Sheet on Ramsar Wetlands (RIS): Wicken Fen |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=13 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011004924/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/pdf/RIS/UK11077.pdf |archivedate=11 October 2012 |df= }} [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]]{{cite web|url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/ProtectedSites/SACselection/sac.asp?EUCode=UK0014782 |title=Fenland SAC |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=13 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170421003841/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/protectedsites/sacselection/sac.asp?EUCode=UK0014782 |archivedate=21 April 2017 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://consult.peterborough.gov.uk/events/3178/full_images/205.pdf|title=Fenland SAC (Woodwalton Fen, Wicken Fen & Chippenham Fen)|publisher=Cambridgeshire County Council|accessdate= 13 December 2016}} |{{Nature on the map|1003251}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003251.pdf Citation] |This is one of the few surviving [[East Anglian]] peat fens, and it has diverse flora and fauna. Herbs include [[Peucedanum palustre|milk parsley]] and [[Lysimachia vulgaris|yellow loosestrife]], and pools have uncommon aquatic plants such as [[Ranunculus flammula|greater spearwort]] and [[lesser water plantain]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003251.pdf |title=Wicken Fen citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=13 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024202831/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003251.pdf |archivedate=24 October 2012 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Wilbraham Fens]] |[[File:Wilbraham Fens 4.jpg|100px|alt=Wilbraham Fens]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 62.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} | align="center"|NO | [[Cambridge]]
{{coord|52.209|0.222 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Wilbraham Fens }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL519591 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1003284}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003284.pdf Citation] |This is an example of a fen habitat, which is now rare in Britain, with grassland, scrub, ponds and ditches. The dominant fen species is [[Phragmites|common reed]], which is present in dense stands, together with plants such as [[purple loosestrife]] and [[Thalictrum flavum|meadow rue]]. Herbs include [[Campanula rotundifolia|harebell]] and [[Knautia arvensis|field scabious]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003284.pdf |title=Wilbraham Fens citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=16 January 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303223753/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003284.pdf |archivedate= 3 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Woodwalton Fen]] |[[File:Gordon's Mere, Woodwalton Fen NNR - geograph.org.uk - 163958.jpg|100px|alt=Woodwalton Fen]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 208.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001698&SiteName=woodwalton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Woodwalton Fen | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 14 December 2016}} | align="center"|YES | [[Ramsey, Cambridgeshire|Ramsey]]

There are rare fen plants such as [[Luzula pallescens|fen wood-rush]] and [[Viola persicifolia|fen violet]], and ditches have uncommon aquatic plants including [[Utricularia vulgaris|bladderwort]] and [[Hottonia palustris|water violet]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001698.pdf |title=Woodwalton Fen citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304064403/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001698.pdf |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Woodwalton Marsh]] |[[File:Wood Walton Marsh - geograph.org.uk - 1243441.jpg|100px|alt=Woodwalton Marsh]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 0.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003320&SiteName=woodwalton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Woodwalton Marsh | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 14 December 2016}} | align="center"|YES | [[Ramsey, Cambridgeshire|Ramsey]]

revision.comment: /* List */ hundreds of asteroids were classified as planets, as were two of Uranus's moons
revision.text:
This is a list of [[astronomical object]]s formerly widely considered [[planet]]s. As of 2016, there are 8 official planets of the [[Solar System]], and many more [[exoplanet]]s. Several objects formerly considered exoplanets have been found to actually be [[star]]s or [[brown dwarf]]s. As the philosophy of [[definition of planet|what is a planet]] has evolved, the [[wikt:en:de facto#English|de facto]] and [[wikt:en:de jure#English|dejure]] definitions of [[wikt:en:planet#English|planet]] have changed over the millennia. ==Background== Throughout antiquity, there have been many [[Classical Planet]]s, once "wandering stars", not all of which are now considered planets. With the advent of the telescope, the [[natural satellite|moons]] initially discovered around [[Jupiter]] and [[Saturn]], were also considered planets by some. The development of more powerful telescopes resulted in the discovery of the [[asteroid]]s, the first many of which were initially considered planets. Then [[Pluto]] was discovered, the first [[Trans-Neptunian Object]]. When electronic imaging came about, Trans-Neptunian Objects of the [[Kuiper Belt]] were found, and then [[Eris (dwarf planet)|Eris]], widely hailed as the "new planet", was discovered, which prompted the [[IAU definition of planet|2006 round of recategorization]] of what is a planet. ==List== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- |+ Former planets of the Solar System |- !class="unsortable"| !| Former planet !| {{tooltip|Discovery|discovery date, planet status conferment}} !| {{tooltip|Removal|planet status removed}} !| {{tooltip|Restored|planet status restored}} As of 2017, no restorations have taken place !| Current status !class="unsortable"| !class="unsortable" width=100%| Notes !class="unsortable"| |- || [[File:Auseklis star.svg|50px|alt=8-pointed star]] || {{sort|Morning Star|[[Phosphorus (morning star)|The Morning Star]]}} || {{sort|-9999|Antiquity}} || {{sort|-400|Antiquity}} | {{n/a}} Not a real object, it is an aspect of the planet Venus || {{sort|Aspect|[[Aspects of Venus]]}} || [[File:Saturn, Moon, Venus and Mercury at dawn - 10 Dec. 2012.jpg|50px]] |rowspan=2| "Phosphorus", the Morning Star of Greek antiquity (''Eosphorus'', the Dawn-Bringer; called "Lucifer" by the Romans), and "Hesperus", the Evening Star (called "Vesper" by the Romans), were later identified as a single planet, [[Venus (planet)|Venus]] (Aphrodite). | rowspan=2| {{cite journal |title= Hesperus and Phosphorus |journal= The Philosophical Review |author= Leonard Linsky |volume= 68 |number= 4 |date= October 1959 |pages= 515–518 |doi= 10.2307/2182495 }} {{cite episode |url= http://www.jackstargazer.com/scripts_feb2009.html |title= The Great Cosmic Light Called Hesperus, Brother Of Lucifer, Reaches Greatest Brilliancy |series= Star Gazer |number= 09-07 (1628) |date= February 2009 }} |- || [[File:Ishtar-star-symbol-simplified-transparent.svg|50px|alt=8-rayed star]] || {{sort|Evening Star|[[Hesperus|The Evening Star]]}} || {{sort|-9999|Antiquity}} || {{sort|-400|Antiquity}} | {{n/a}} || {{sort|Aspect|[[Aspects of Venus]]}} || [[File:Winterabend im Dorf Cyriaxweimar in Elnhausen-Michelbacher Senke mit Venus am Nachthimmel, Radroute von Marburg-Stadtwald 2016-12-30.jpg|50px]] |- || [[File:Sun symbol.svg|50px|alt=☉]] || [[Sun]] || {{sort|-9999|Antiquity}} || 1700s || — || [[Star]] || [[File:Solar prominence from STEREO spacecraft September 29, 2008.jpg|50px]] || Following the acceptance of the [[Copernican model]], the Sun was recognized as not being a planet, as it was the center, and did not orbit the center. || {{cite web |url= http://www.universetoday.com/36487/difference-between-geocentric-and-heliocentric/ |title= What Is The Difference Between the Geocentric and Heliocentric Models of the Solar System? |date= 23 December 2015 |publisher= Universe Today |author= Elizabeth Howell }} {{cite web |url= http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/Features/OrbitsHistory/page1.php |title= Planetary Motion: The History of an Idea That Launched the Scientific Revolution |author= Holli Riebeek |date= 7 July 2009 |work= The Science: Orbital Mechanics |publisher= NASA Earth Observatory }} {{cite web |url= http://www.pas.rochester.edu/~blackman/ast104/copernican9.html |title= The Copernican Model: A Sun-Centered Solar System |work= Astronomy 104 -- The Solar System |date= 2006 |author= Eric G. Blackman |publisher= University of Rochester, School of Arts and Sciences, Department of Physics and Astronomy }} |- || [[File:Crescent.svg|50px|alt=☾]] || [[Moon]] || {{sort|-9999|Antiquity}} || 1700s || — || {{sort|Moon|[[Natural satellite|Moon]] of Earth}} || [[File:The Moon Luc Viatour.jpg|50px]] || Following the acceptance of the [[Copernican model]], the Moon was recognized as not being a planet, as it orbited the Earth, and did not orbit the center, the Sun. || |- || || [[Io (moon)|Io]] || 1610 || 1700s || — || {{sort|Moon|[[Natural satellite|Moon]] of Jupiter}} || [[File:PIA01667-Io's Pele Hemisphere After Pillan Changes.jpg|50px]] | rowspan=4|Originally presented as satellite planets orbiting the planet Jupiter. Planetary status later rescinded, leaving them only as satellites. | rowspan=4| {{la icon}} {{cite journal |title= Sidereus Nuncius |author= Galileo Galilei |year= 1610 }} {{cite web |url= http://galileo.rice.edu/sci/observations/jupiter_satellites.html |title= Satellites of Jupiter |date= 1995 |author= Al Van Helden |work= The Galileo Project |publisher= Rice University }} {{cite web |url= http://solarviews.com/eng/galdisc.htm |title= The Discovery of the Galilean Satellites |publisher= Views of the Solar System |author= Calvin J. Hamilton |date= 2009 }} {{cite journal |url= http://inference-review.com/article/the-provencal-humanists-and-copernicus |title= Montaigne, Peiresc, Gassendi, and Cassini - The Provençal Humanists and Copernicus |author= Jean-Pierre Luminet |volume= 2 |number= 4 |journal= Inference: International Review of Science |date= 31 December 2016 }} |- || || [[Europa (moon)|Europa]] || 1610 || 1700s || — || {{sort|Moon|[[Natural satellite|Moon]] of Jupiter}} || [[File:Europa - September 1997 (16411900725).jpg|50px]] |- || || [[Ganymede (moon)|Ganymede]] || 1610 || 1700s || — || {{sort|Moon|[[Natural satellite|Moon]] of Jupiter}} || [[File:Ganymede g1 true (mod).jpg|50px]] |- || || [[Callisto (moon)|Callisto]] || 1610 || 1700s || — || {{sort|Moon|[[Natural satellite|Moon]] of Jupiter}} || [[File:Callisto - PIA00457 (cropped).jpg|50px]] |- || || [[Titan (moon)|Titan]] || 1656 || 1700s || — || {{sort|Moon|[[Natural satellite|Moon]] of Saturn}} || [[File:Lakes Through the Haze.jpg|50px]] | rowspan=5|Originally presented as satellite planets orbiting the planet Saturn. Planetary status later rescinded, leaving them only as satellites. || {{la icon}} {{cite journal |title= Systema Saturnium |author= Cristiani Hugenii (Christiaan Huygens) |year= 1659 }} |- || || [[Iapetus (moon)|Iapetus]] || 1671 || 1700s || — || {{sort|Moon|[[Natural satellite|Moon]] of Saturn}} || [[File:Japeto es una luna de saturno.jpg|50px]] | rowspan=2| {{fr icon}} {{cite journal |title= Découverte de deux nouvelles planètes autour de Saturne |author= Jean-Dominique Cassini (Giovanni Domenico Cassini) |year= 1673 |publisher= Paris Observatory }} |- || || [[Rhea (moon)|Rhea]] || 1672 || 1700s || — || {{sort|Moon|[[Natural satellite|Moon]] of Saturn}} || [[File:Rhea (moon) from Voyager 1.jpg|50px]] |- || || [[Tethys (moon)|Tethys]] || 1684 || 1700s || — || {{sort|Moon|[[Natural satellite|Moon]] of Saturn}} || [[File:Tethys near true.jpg|50px]] | rowspan=2| {{cite journal |doi= 10.1098/rstl.1686.0013 |author = Jean-Dominique Cassini (Giovanni Domenico Cassini) |year= 1686–1692 |title= An Extract of the Journal Des Scavans. Of April 22 st. N. 1686. Giving an Account of Two New Satellites of Saturn, Discovered Lately by Mr. Cassini at the Royal Observatory at Paris |journal= Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London |volume= 16 |issue= 179–191 |pages= 79–85 |jstor= 101844 }} |- || || [[Dione (moon)|Dione]] || 1684 || 1700s || — || {{sort|Moon|[[Natural satellite|Moon]] of Saturn}} || [[File:Dione from Voyager 1 (1980).jpg|50px]] |- || || [[Titania (moon)|Titania]] || 1787 || || — || {{sort|Moon|[[Natural satellite|Moon]] of Uranus}} || | rowspan=2|Originally presented as satellite planets orbiting the planet Uranus. Planetary status later rescinded, leaving them only as satellites. || |- || || [[Oberon (moon)|Oberon]] || 1787 || || — || {{sort|Moon|[[Natural satellite|Moon]] of Uranus}} || || |- || [[File:Ceres2.svg|50px|alt=⚳]] || [[1 Ceres|Ceres]] || 1801 || 1860s || — || [[Asteroid]] and [[dwarf planet]] || [[File:Ceres - PIA19619 (cropped).jpg|50px]] |rowspan=4| The first hundred or so asteroids to be discovered were accepted as planets in the Copernican system, as they directly orbited the Sun. With the discovery of many more asteroids, and due to the recognition that unlike the traditional planets they had overlapping orbits, they came to be considered 'minor planets' or 'asteroids' instead, though that process would take longest for the first four to be discovered (Ceres, Pallas, Juno, Vesta). | rowspan=4| {{cite web|url=http://aa.usno.navy.mil/faq/docs/minorplanets.php |title=When did the asteroids become minor planets? |author=James L. Hilton |date=18 April 2016 |work=Astronomical Applications Department |publisher=U.S. Naval Observatory |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080324182332/http://aa.usno.navy.mil/faq/docs/minorplanets.php |archivedate=24 March 2008 |df= }} |- || [[File:2Pallas symbol.svg|50px|alt=⚴]] || [[2 Pallas|Pallas]] || 1802 || 1860s || — || [[Asteroid]] || [[File:PallasHST2007.jpg|50px]] |- || [[File:3 Juno (1).svg|50px|alt=⚵]] || [[3 Juno|Juno]] || 1804 || 1860s || — || [[Asteroid]] || [[File:Juno from Hooker telescope.jpg|50px]] |- || [[File:4 Vesta (1).svg|50px|alt=⚶]] || [[4 Vesta|Vesta]] || 1807 || 1860s || — || [[Asteroid]] || [[File:Vesta nasa.jpg|50px]] |- || [[File:Pluto symbol.svg|50px|alt=♇]]
[[File:Pluto's astrological symbol.svg|50px]] || [[Pluto]] || 1930 || 2006 || — || [[Dwarf planet]] || [[File:Global LORRI mosaic of Pluto in true colour.jpg|50px]] || Following the discovery of [[Eris (dwarf planet)|Eris]], the [[International Astronomical Union]] met to hammer out a definition of planet, as Eris being larger than Pluto, pressured the IAU into making a formal statement on the matter. Either there were to be many planets, or the decision made at the time the asteroids were removed would be repeated. Pluto and Eris, and similar bodies were lumped together like the asteroids before them, and removed, being as representatives of a large group of smaller objects. Pluto would be listed as a "dwarf planet" from the reshuffle. || {{cite news |url= http://www.space.com/2791-pluto-demoted-longer-planet-highly-controversial-definition.html |title= Pluto Demoted: No Longer a Planet in Highly Controversial Definition |date= 24 August 2006 |author= Robert Roy Britt |publisher= SPACE.com }} |- || [[File:Chiron symbol.svg|50px|alt=⚷]] || [[2060 Chiron|Chiron]] || 1977 || 1980 || — || {{sort|Centaur|[[Centaur (minor planet)|Centaur]]}} || || The discovery of Chiron was hailed by the press and astrologers as that of a new planet. Astronomically, it was different from other objects, asteroids and comets, known at the time, and was classified independently uniquely at that time. Later, it was called an [[asteroid]] and then exhibited characteristics of a [[comet]], leading to multiple classifications. Later it was placed into its own category of [[Centaur (minor planet)|Centaur]]s. || {{cite journal |title= The Discovery of Chiron: Some Reflections |author= Hodgson, Richard G. |journal= The Minor Planet Bulletin |volume= 5 |number= 3 |pages= 21–22 |publicationdate= March 1978 |bibcode= 1978MPBu....5...21H |publisher= IAU MPC }} {{cite web |url= https://www.spiritualastrology.com/article15.html |title= Chiron and the Centaurs |date= 2004 |work= Emerald Visions |publisher= Mystic Visions Spiritual Astrology }} {{cite book |title= Chiron: Rainbow Bridge Between the Inner and Outer Planets |author= Barbara Hand Clow |year= 1987 |isbn= 087542094X |publisher= Llewellyn }} {{cite book |title= Chiron: The New Planet in Your Horoscope, The Key to Your Quest |author= Richard Nolle |isbn= 0866902368 |year= 1983 |publisher= American Federation of Astrologers }} {{cite magazine |title= In Greenwich |magazine= Popular Mechanics |date= January 1982 |volume= 158 |number= 1 |page= 28 }} |- || [[File:Charon symbol proposal.svg|50px]] || [[Charon (moon)|Charon]] || 1978 || 2006 || — || {{sort|Moon|[[Natural satellite|Moon]] of Pluto}} || [[File:Charon-9-10-15.jpg|50px]] || When discovered, Charon, the moon of Pluto, was found to be very large, leading to the declaration by many that the [[Pluto-Charon system]] was a [[double planet]] (binary planet). The 2006 IAU redefinition of planet removed the possibility of double planets being within the definition. || {{cite web |url= http://archive.oapd.inaf.it/E-MOSTRA/NEW/A2024PLU.HTM |title= Pluto and Charon |author= E. Mostra |work= Voyage in the Universe |date= 1998 |publisher= Astronomical Observatory of Padua }} |- || [[File:Five fingered hand of Eris symbol.svg|50px]] || [[Eris (dwarf planet)|Eris]] || 2005 || 2006 || — || [[Dwarf planet]] || [[File:Eris and dysnomia-cut.jpg|50px]] || The discovery of Eris, hailed worldwide by the press as the 10th planet, prompted the [[International Astronomical Union]] to meet to hammer out a definition of planet. Its discovery pointed to a future of many more similar discoveries, forming an analogue to the time when asteroids were first discovered. In a similar fashion, all such objects were again lumped together, out of the planet club. Eris would be listed as a "dwarf planet" from the reshuffle. || {{cite web |url= http://www.space.com/9563-man-killed-pluto-astronomer-mike-brown.html |title= The Man Who Killed Pluto: Q & A with Astronomer Mike Brown |author= Mike Wall |date= 19 November 2010 |publisher= SPACE.com }} {{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/4730061.stm |date= 30 July 2005 |title= Astronomers detect '10th planet' |author= David Whitehouse |publisher= BBC News }} |- |} ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=NB}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== * [[List of gravitationally rounded objects of the Solar System]] * [[List of possible dwarf planets]] * [[List of hypothetical Solar System objects]] {{Solar System}} {{Exoplanet}} [[Category:Lists of planets|Former planets]] [[Category:Lists of former entities|Planets]]

page.title: List of most massive black holes

revision.comment: Added free to read link in citations with [[WP:OABOT|OAbot]] #oabot
revision.text:
{{pp-protected|reason=Persistent [[WP:Disruptive editing|disruptive editing]]|small=yes}} [[File:BlackHole.jpg|thumb|right|350 px|An artist's impression of a [[supermassive black hole]] devouring matter from an accretion disc]] This is an ordered '''list of the most massive [[black hole]]s''' so far discovered (and probable candidates), measured in units of [[solar mass]]es ({{Solar mass|link=yes}}), or the mass of the [[Sun]] (approx. {{val|2|e=30}} kilograms). == Introduction == A [[supermassive black hole]] (SMBH) is the largest type of black hole, on the order of hundreds of thousands to billions of [[solar masses]] ({{Solar mass|link=y}}), and is theorized to exist in the center of almost all massive [[Galaxy|galaxies]]. Unambiguous dynamical evidence for SMBHs exists only in a handful of galaxies;{{cite book |last=Merritt|first=David|authorlink=David Merritt|title=Dynamics and Evolution of Galactic Nuclei |url=http://press.princeton.edu/titles/10040.html |date=2013 |publisher=Princeton University Press |location=Princeton, NJ |isbn=978-0-691-15860-0 |page=23}} these include the [[Milky Way]], the [[Local Group]] galaxies [[Andromeda Galaxy|M31]] and [[Messier 32|M32]], and a few galaxies beyond the Local Group, e.g. [[NGC 4395]]. In these galaxies, the mean square (or root mean square) velocities of the stars or gas rises as ~1/r near the center, indicating a central point mass. In all other galaxies observed to date, the rms velocities are flat, or even falling, toward the center, making it impossible to state with certainty that a supermassive black hole is present. Nevertheless, it is commonly accepted that the center of nearly every galaxy contains a supermassive black hole.{{cite journal |last=King|first=Andrew|date=2003-09-15|title=Black Holes, Galaxy Formation, and the MBH-σ Relation|journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters |volume=596 |pages=L27–L29|arxiv = astro-ph/0308342 |bibcode = 2003ApJ...596L..27K |doi = 10.1086/379143 }} The reason for this assumption is the [[M-sigma relation]], a tight (low scatter) relation between the mass of the hole in the ~10 galaxies with secure detections, and the velocity dispersion of the stars in the bulges of those galaxies.{{cite journal |bibcode=2000ApJ...539L...9F |last1=Ferrarese| first1=Laura|last2=Merritt| first2=David|authorlink2=David Merritt|date=2000-08-10|title=A Fundamental Relation between Supermassive Black Holes and Their Host Galaxies|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|publisher=The American Astronomical Society |pages=L9–12|doi=10.1086/312838|issue=1|volume=539|arxiv = astro-ph/0006053 }} This correlation, although based on just a handful of galaxies, suggests to many astronomers a strong connection between the formation of the black hole and the galaxy itself. Although SMBHs are currently theorized to exist in almost all massive galaxies, more massive black holes are rare; with only fewer than several dozen having been discovered to date. There is extreme difficulty in determining a mass of a particular SMBH, and so they still remain in the field of open research. SMBHs with accurate masses are limited only to galaxies within the [[Laniakea Supercluster]] and to [[active galactic nuclei]]. Another problem for this list is the method used in determining the mass. Such methods, such as broad emission-line [[reverberation mapping]] (BLRM), [[Doppler effect#Astronomy|Doppler measurement]]s, [[velocity dispersion]], and the [[M-sigma relation]] have not yet been well established. Most of the time, the masses derived from the given methods contradict each other's values. This list contains supermassive black holes with known masses, determined at least to the order of magnitude. Some objects in this list have two citations, like 3C 273; one from Bradley M. Peterson ''et al.'' using the BLRM method,{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s11214-013-9987-4 | title = Measuring the Masses of Supermassive Black Holes | journal = Space Science Reviews | volume = 183 | page = 253 | url = http://www.astronomy.ohio-state.edu/~peterson/Docs/petersonISSI.pdf | year = 2013 | last1 = Peterson | first1 = Bradley M. | bibcode = 2014SSRv..183..253P }} and the other from Charles Nelson using [OIII]λ5007 value and velocity dispersion.{{cite journal|doi=10.1086/317314|title=Black Hole Mass, Velocity Dispersion, and the Radio Source in Active Galactic Nuclei|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|volume=544|issue=2|pages=L91|year=2000|last1=Nelson|first1=Charles H.|bibcode=2000ApJ...544L..91N|arxiv = astro-ph/0009188 }} Note that this list is very far from complete, as the [[Sloan Digital Sky Survey]] (SDSS) alone detected {{val|200,000}} [[quasars]], which likely may be the homes of billion-solar-mass black holes. In addition, there are several hundred citations for black hole measurements not yet included on this list. Despite this, the majority of well-known black holes above 1 billion {{Solar mass|link=y}} are shown. Messier galaxies with precisely known black holes are all included. == List == {{expand list|date=June 2017}} Listed black holes here have issues of measurement accuracies and more importantly the mass estimates are based on different kinds of evaluation methods which are all affected by their own individual systematics. {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ '''List of most massive black holes''' |- ! style="background:#efefef; white-space:nobr;"|Name ! style="background:#ffdead;"| [[Solar mass]]
([[Sun]] = 1) ! Notes |- | [[TON 618]] || '''{{val|6.6|e=10}}'''{{cite journal|last1=Shemmer|first1=O.|last2=Netzer|first2=H.|last3=Maiolino|first3=R.|last4=Oliva|first4=E.|last5=Croom|first5=S.|last6=Corbett|first6=E.|last7=di Fabrizio|first7=L.|title=Near-infrared spectroscopy of high-redshift active galactic nuclei. I. A metallicity-accretion rate relationship|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2004|volume=614|issue=2|pages=547–557|url=http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1086/423607/pdf|arxiv=astro-ph/0406559|bibcode=2004ApJ...614..547S|doi=10.1086/423607}} ||Estimated from quasar Hβ emission line correlation. |- | [[IC 1101]] || '''{{val|4|-|10|e=10}}'''{{cite journal|last1=Dullo|first1=Bililign T.|last2=Graham|first2=Alister W.|last3=Knapen|first3=Johan H.|title=A remarkably large depleted core in the Abell 2029 BCG IC 1101|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|date=October 2017|volume=471|issue=2|pages=2321–2333|doi=10.1093/mnras/stx1635|arxiv=1707.02277|bibcode=2017MNRAS.471.2321D}} || |- |[[S5 0014+81#Supermassive black hole|S5 0014+81]] || '''{{val|4e10}}'''{{cite journal| title = Chasing the heaviest black holes in active galactic nuclei, the largest black hole | journal = Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society | volume = 405 | page = 387 | arxiv = 0912.0001 |bibcode = 2010MNRAS.405..387G |doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.16449.x | year = 2010 | last1 = Ghisellini | first1 = G. | last2 = Ceca | first2 = R. Della | last3 = Volonteri | first3 = M. | last4 = Ghirlanda | first4 = G. | last5 = Tavecchio | first5 = F. | last6 = Foschini | first6 = L. | last7 = Tagliaferri | first7 = G. | last8 = Haardt | first8 = F. | last9 = Pareschi | first9 = G. | last10 = Grindlay | first10 = J. }}{{Cite journal|last=Ghisellini|first=G. |last2=Foschini|first2=L. |arxiv=0906.0575 |title=The blazar S5 0014+813: a real or apparent monster? |journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society: Letters |volume=399 |pages=L24 |date=14 July 2009 |version=v2 |last3=Volonteri |first3= M. |last4= Ghirlanda |first4=G. |last5= Haardt |first5=F. |last6= Burlon |first6=D. |last7= Tavecchio |first7=F. |doi=10.1111/j.1745-3933.2009.00716.x |bibcode = 2009MNRAS.399L..24G |display-authors=etal}}{{cite book |title=Extreme Cosmos: A Guided Tour of the Fastest, Brightest, Hottest, Heaviest, Oldest, and Most Amazing Aspects of Our Universe |url=https://books.google.com/?id=RNvQsCMq920C&pg=PT103&lpg=PT103&dq=largest+black+hole+extreme+cosmos#v=onepage&q=largest%20black%20hole%20extreme%20cosmos&f=false |accessdate=8 December 2014|isbn=978-1-101-58701-0 |last1=Gaensler |first1=Bryan |date=2012-07-03 }}|| A 2010 paper suggested that a funnel collimates the radiation around the jet axis, creating an optical illusion of very high brightness, and thus a possible overestimation of the black hole mass. |- |[[SDSS J102325.31+514251.0]] || '''{{val|3.31|0.61|e=10}}''' ||Estimated from quasar MgII emission line correlation. |- |[[H1821+643]] || '''{{val|3e10}}''' || Nearest galaxy cluster harboring a quasar in its core.{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/mnras/stu1067| arxiv=1405.7522v1 |last1 = Walker |first1 = S. M. |display-authors=etal | title = Measuring Distance and Properties of the Milky Way's Central Supermassive Black Hole with Stellar Orbits | journal = Astrophysical Journal | date = 2008 | volume = 689 | issue = 2 | pages = 1044–1062 | doi = 10.1086/592738 | bibcode = 2008ApJ...689.1044G | arxiv=0808.2870|last2=Salim |last3=Weinberg |last4=Lu |last5=Do |last6=Dunn |last7=Matthews |last8=Morris |last9=Yelda |last10=Becklin |last11=Kremenek |last12=Milosavljevic |last13=Naiman }} || The black hole at the center of the [[Milky Way]]. |} == See also == * [[List of largest cosmic structures]] * [[List of largest galaxies]] * [[List of most massive stars]] * [[List of most massive exoplanets]] * [[List of the most distant astronomical objects]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} {{Black holes}} [[Category:Supermassive black holes|*]] [[Category:Lists of astronomical objects]] [[Category:Lists of superlatives in astronomy|Black holes, Most massive]]

page.title: List of storms in the 2005 Atlantic hurricane season

revision.comment: It's too redundant.
revision.text:
[[File:2005 Atlantic hurricane season summary map.png|right|thumb|Summary map of the 2005 Atlantic hurricane season]] The [[2005 Atlantic hurricane season]] officially began June 1, 2005 and officially ended on November 30, 2005. These dates conventionally delimit the period of each year when most [[tropical cyclone]]s form in the [[Atlantic basin]], although effectively the season persisted into January 2006 due to continued storm activity.
{| |- |rowspan=4| '''Related articles''' |'''[[2005 Atlantic hurricane season]]''' |- |[[2005 Atlantic hurricane season statistics]] |- |[[Timeline of the 2005 Atlantic hurricane season]] |- |}
The 2005 season was the most active season on record, shattering records on repeated occasions. A record 28 tropical and subtropical storms formed, of which a record fifteen became hurricanes. Of these, seven strengthened into major hurricanes, a record-tying five became [[category 4 hurricane]]s, a record four of which reached Category 5 strength, the highest categorization for [[North Atlantic tropical cyclone]]s. Among these Category 5 storms was [[Hurricane Wilma]], the most intense hurricane ever recorded in the Atlantic. The most notable storms of the season were the five Category 4 and Category 5 hurricanes: [[Hurricane Dennis|Dennis]], [[Hurricane Emily (2005)|Emily]], [[Hurricane Katrina|Katrina]], [[Hurricane Rita|Rita]], and [[Hurricane Wilma|Wilma]], along with the Category 1 [[Hurricane Stan]]. These storms made a combined twelve landfalls as major hurricanes (Category 3 strength or higher) throughout [[Cuba]], [[Mexico]], and the [[Gulf Coast of the United States]], causing over $180 billion (2005 [[USD]]) in damages and at least 3,960 deaths. __NOTOC__
{| id="toc" border="0" ! {{MediaWiki:toc}} | |

text-align:center;" title="Unnamed, Subtropical Storm"|SS |[[#2005 Azores subtropical storm|Unnamed]] |} | {| width="16.7%" style="background:transparent;" |- |style="background-color: #{{storm colour|storm}};
